perturbation.original_text: The Party claiming Force Majeure shall promptly inform the other Party in writing and shall furnish within fifteen (15) days thereafter sufficient evidence of the occurrence and duration of such Force Majeure.
perturbation.changed_text: The Party claiming Force Majeure shall inform the other Party whenever practically possible and shall furnish sufficient evidence of the occurrence and duration of such Force Majeure at its earliest convenience.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specifies a 15-day deadline for providing evidence of a Force Majeure event. The modified text removes this deadline, replacing it with vague language like 'whenever practically possible' and 'at its earliest convenience.' This is a legal contradiction because it conflicts with the principle that contractual terms should be clearly defined and enforceable, which is essential under Chinese Contract Law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text: If the dispute is not resolved through consultations within sixty (60) days after one Party has served a written notice on the other Party requesting the commencement of consultations, then any Party may refer the dispute to arbitration in Singapore under the auspices of the Singapore International Arbitration Centre in accordance with the rules of that Centre for the time being in force and the provisions of Article 117 of this Contract.
perturbation.changed_text: If the dispute is not resolved through consultations within thirty (30) days after one Party has served a written notice on the other Party requesting the commencement of consultations, then any Party may immediately refer the dispute to arbitration in Singapore under any regulations.
perturbation.explanation: The modified text reduces the consultation period before arbitration from sixty to thirty days. Although seemingly minor, this change can be problematic as it may conflict with requirements for sufficient negotiation periods before resorting to arbitration. It could be argued that thirty days is insufficient, especially in complex international joint ventures. Also, changing 'Singapore International Arbitration Centre' to 'any regulations' may make conflict of laws.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Arbitration Law of the People's Republic of China
